newsitem.title: PHILIPPINES: Manila shares inch up at close in light trade.
newsitem.headline: Manila shares inch up at close in light trade.

text.p: Manila shares ended a shade up on Tuesday after see-saw trading as losses of most B shares were slightly offset by gains of index heavyweight Metrobank, traders said.
"The market is consolidating and we are welcoming back Mr. Volatility," said Kenneth Nerecina, research head at Vickers Ballas Securities Phils Inc.
Turnover was a thin 1.95 billion pesos.
In the broader market, bears overpowered bulls with 69 decliners against 57 gainers.

Joey Roxas, president at Eagle Equities Inc said reports of foreign investors being allowed by the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) to own A shares reserved for Filipinos caused the selloff in Manila Electric Co (Meralco) B shares.
Foreigners are limited to buying Class B shares.
Meralco opened at an intra-day low of 100 pesos from the previous 120 but recovered by the close at 112 pesos. It was the most heavily traded issue.
During trading, the SEC made no official comment on foreigners being allowed to own A shares.
But after the session, SEC executive director Eugenio Reyes told Reuters that foreigners in theory have have been able to purchase A shares since the late 1980s by using a Philippine-owned fund.

"But it's not simple. An arrangement has to be made with a trustee bank with Filipino owners and voting rights, as well as ownership of the B shares, will be maintained by the trustee bank," said Reyes.
